newsitem.title: CHINA: FOCUS-China stocks end mostly up but sentiment weak.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-China stocks end mostly up but sentiment weak.

text.p: China's share indices ended mostly higher on a technical rebound on Friday after a week of steep falls, but brokers said market sentiment was weak on fears of further anti-speculation measures by authorities.
The Shanghai B index fell 0.196 points or 0.24 percent to 82.387 points while the Shenzhen B index rose 2.33 points or 1.55 percent to 153.19.
Shanghai's A share index gained 20.514 points or 1.59 percent to 1,310.627 points and the Shenzhen A index rose 3.58 points or 0.85 percent to 425.72.
"The indices rose on bargain-hunting as short-term technical indicators showed stocks looked oversold after yesterday's sharp drops," an analyst at Shenzhen J&A Securities said.
"The markets have not bottomed out and strong downward pressure looms ahead."
Brokers said the movement of the indices on Monday would depend on whether there were further announcements over the weekend by the government to cool down stock trading.
"It's very clear that Beijing is determined to dampen share volatility and investors will be bearish about the markets in the near future," an analyst at Central-South Securities said.

Beijing on Wednesday announced it would ban state enterprises and listed firms from speculative stock trading, a move brokers said was clearly aimed at curbing the inflow of "hot money" into the country's overheated stock markets.
The announcement sent share prices in Shenzhen and Shanghai into freefall on Thursday.
"Institutions are not willing to build large positions under such unfavourable conditions," one broker said. "More clampdown measures are seen as being possible in the short term."
On the Shanghai B share market, Shanghai Rubber Belt was the biggest loser, plunging $0.020 or 8.84 percent to $0.206 on volume of 50,000 shares.
Inner Mongolia Erdos Cashmere was the most actively traded with its 100 million new shares listed today. It slipped $0.060 or 6.55 percent to $0.856 on volume of 5.3 million shares.

On the Shenzhen B share market, newcomer Nanjing Posts & Telecommunication was the most actively traded with a volume of 6.93 million shares. It rose HK$0.20 or 4.81 percent to HK$4.36 on institutional buying, brokers said.
Nanjing Posts, which issued 100 million B shares at HK$2.43 per share earlier this month, began trading on Thursday.

On the Shenzhen A share market, Shenzhen Development Bank rose 2.41 yuan or 6.58 percent to 39.05 yuan, the most heavily traded counter with 41 million shares changing hands, despite a continuing investigation into alleged stock trading irregularities.
Traders said investors happy with the bank's dividend plans, to be confirmed at a shareholders' meeting next Monday.
